technical_concept:
The terminal is your window into the file system.

pwd — shows where you are (Print Working Directory).
ls — lists files and folders. Add -la for hidden files and details.
cd — changes directory. cd .. goes up, cd ~ goes home.
mkdir — creates new directories.

code_example.code:
pwd
# /home/user

ls -la
# drwxr-xr-x  2 user user 4096 Jan 1 00:00 documents
# -rw-r--r--  1 user user  123 Jan 1 00:00 notes.txt

cd documents
mkdir projects

challenge.hint: Which command creates a new directory?

dialogue.line: You open your eyes. Pine trees tower above you. The air smells like rain and earth. Your backpack is gone, your phone is dead — but there's a terminal glowing softly on a rock beside you.
SYSTEM ONLINE. Welcome, survivor. I am your only connection to the outside world. Through me, you can navigate, build, and survive.
Type 'pwd' — Print Working Directory. It will tell you exactly where you are in this wilderness.
Now type 'ls' to look around. It lists everything in your current location — files, directories, resources. Add '-la' to see hidden items and details. Knowledge is survival.
I see some files... and a 'forest' directory. How do I go there?

'cd forest' moves you into it. 'cd ..' brings you back. Think of directories as trails — you walk in, you walk out. And 'mkdir' creates a new shelter — a new directory. First things first: set up camp.
A dimly lit room. A single laptop on a steel table. You sit down. A voice crackles through the earpiece.
Welcome to the team, rookie. Codename: Ghost. I'm your handler. Everything we do goes through the terminal. No GUI, no traces.
I'm in. What's the first move?
Rule one: always know where you are. Type 'pwd' — Print Working Directory. If you don't know your position, you're already compromised.
Got it. /ops/staging. And I need to see what's here?
'ls' — list everything. Use 'ls -la' for the full intel: hidden files, permissions, timestamps. In this business, the hidden stuff matters most.
I see directories: vault, comms, extraction. How do I move?
'cd vault' gets you in. 'cd ..' pulls you out. And 'mkdir' creates a new drop point — a directory for stashing files. Set up a staging area. We're going to need it.
